metadata.case_name: Newspapers Ltd., Allahabad v. State of U.P. and others

facts.text: Tajammul Hussain, respondent No. 3, was employed as a linotypist by the appellant company.
Tajammul Hussain was dismissed on May 8, 1952, on allegations of incompetence under r. 12(ii) of the Standing Orders of the appellant company.
Dismissal of respondent No. 3 was welcomed by his co-workers and other workmen; they made no grievance of it and did not espouse his cause.
Case of respondent No. 3 was not taken up by any union of workers of the appellant company or by any unions of workmen in similar or allied trades.
P. Working Journalists Union, Lucknow, with which respondent No. 3 had no connection, took the matter to the Conciliation Board, Allahabad.
U.P. Government made a reference to the Industrial Tribunal on June 3, 1953, by notification stating an industrial dispute exists between Newspapers Ltd., Allahabad and its workmen.
One question referred: Whether the services of Sri Tajammul Hussain Lino Operator were wrongfully terminated by the Management.

State Industrial Tribunal at Allahabad on February 13, 1953, decided in favour of respondent No. 3, ordered reinstatement without break of continuity of service and payment of wages for the dismissed period.
Appellant company appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal, which by order dated February 24, 1953, affirmed the Tribunal's order with costs.
Appellant company filed petition in Allahabad High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution; dismissed by Bhargava J. on January 6, 1954.
Special Appeal No. 8 of 1954 against High Court judgment dismissed on September 22, 1954.
Appellant company appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether a dispute between an employer and a single workman falls within the definition of 'industrial dispute' as used in the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Whether the U.P. Government had power to make the reference in question absent an industrial dispute.

petitioner_arguments.text: No industrial dispute existed within the meaning of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and consequently the U.P. Government had no power to make the reference.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2 of U.P. Act (same as s.2(k) Central Act); scheme of U.P. Act

court_reasoning.text: The scheme of the U.P. Act is to maintain industrial peace via collective amity; individual disputes excluded unless espoused by workmen as a body or considerable section, creating conditions under s.3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions like rr.4,5,15 do not extend 'industrial dispute' to individual cases; s.13(2) General Clauses Act considered but overall intent is collective disputes.

court_reasoning.text: Awards bind all workmen and future entrants (s.18 Central Act), supporting collectiveness; r.26 prohibits changes during pendency for groups.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules cannot enlarge statutory definition of industrial dispute.

court_reasoning.text: Reference under s.3(c),(d),(g) assumes dispute between employer and workmen; here it was individual, so invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Party can challenge lack of industrial dispute despite administrative reference power.

holdings.text: A dispute between an employer and a single workman is not an 'industrial dispute' under U.P. Act unless it acquires collective characteristics by being espoused by group of workmen.
No industrial dispute existed; reference invalid; Tribunal lacked jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan
precedents_cited.relevance: Discussed three views on individual disputes; preferred view that individual dispute becomes industrial if taken up by union or number of workmen.
Industrial dispute affects large groups; single case may develop into one if taken by union.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. C.P. Sarathy
precedents_cited.relevance: Reference is administrative but jurisdiction can be challenged if no industrial dispute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kandan Textile Ltd. v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual dispute not industrial despite wide definition, considering s.18.

precedents_cited.case_name: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Held individual dispute is industrial; overruled as incorrect.

precedents_cited.case_name: Metal Trades Employers Association v. Amalgamated Engineering Union

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines industrial dispute; empowers reference only for collective disputes to maintain peace.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (Central)
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition adopted; awards bind all workmen; supports collective nature.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ and SC appeal.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Singular includes plural, but not decisive against collective intent.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of Industrial Tribunal, Labour Appellate Tribunal, and Allahabad High Court set aside as no industrial dispute existed and reference was invalid.
outcome.relief_granted: Orders setting aside the Tribunal's award of reinstatement and back wages for Tajammul Hussain.

key_quotes.text: The provisions of the U.P. Act show that the machinery of the Act has been devised with the object of maintaining industrial peace so as to prevent interference with public safety or public order...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and excludes individual disputes.

key_quotes.text: a single employee's case might develop into an industrial dispute, when... it is taken up by the trade union of which he is a member and there is a concerted demand by the employees for redress.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when individual dispute becomes industrial.

key_quotes.text: the dispute of an individual workman was not intended to be the subject of an adjudication under the Act, when the same had not been taken up by the union or a number of workmen.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding from prior SC precedent applied.
